heading: a slow twist on quicktime
subheading: a microsoft manager denies that his company tried to disable apple's multimedia software, saying that if there were problems with quicktime, apple brought them on itself. declan mccullagh reports from washington.
author: declan mccullagh
text: washington -- in a emotional climax to his testimony on the witness stand, a microsoft manager insisted that his company had not tried to cripple apple computer's quicktime multimedia software. "at microsoft, our company would never do something like that," said eric engstrom, a microsoft network general manager.during the first days of the trial, an apple executive accused microsoft of strong-arming the cupertino company in an attempt to "sabotage" rival technology. "microsoft has used various anti-competitive actions to thwart the growth of quicktime," avadis tevanian said in written testimony.for a window onto the microsoft antitrust trial, visit us v. microsoft. - - - - - -he claimed microsoft engineers inserted misleading error messages when people tried to use quicktime and altered windows so that quicktime sometimes didn't work properly. "microsoft has taken steps to impede the adoption and use of quicktime 3.0," tevanian testified.but engstrom, who formerly was involved with microsoft's multimedia efforts, swore that his employer "just doesn't do" that kind of thing. in fact, he said, tevanian's "inflammatory accusations" caused problems when microsoft executives started asking for explanations."i spent a fair amount of time explaining to my management," engstrom said. "this could have ... serious impacts to me personally."in his written direct testimony, engstrom lists a series of "significant errors" he said apple made when developing quicktime. his claim: apple brought any problems on itself.in fact, engstrom said, microsoft asked three independent labs to look into the who-did-what-to-whom dispute. "in less than a week, mindcraft confirmed microsoft's conclusion that most of the problems with quicktime for windows result from programming errors made by apple," he said.
